title: How leaves change colour in fall [Photos]
text:
Friday, October 25, 2013 11:59 AM EDT | Updated: Wednesday, September 23, 2015 10:44 AM EDT Top 10 places to see fall foliage in Canada Previous Next 
Prince Edward Island: From mid-September to late October, P.E.I. is alive with colour as the leaves change. Drive through the middle of the province on the Central Coastal Drive. Offering picturesque views of cliffs, beaches, sea and, of course, fall foliage, the 253 km route is a great way to explore P.E.I. in autumn. (Fotolia) 
Niagara region, Ontario: Niagara Falls, Niagara-on-the-Lake and the Niagara River Parkway are all must-visit areas during autumn. Not only can you sample some of the best wines in Canada in Niagara-on-the-Lake, but you can also view Niagara Falls surrounded by autumn colours or just tour the foliage on the lovely Parkway drive. (Fotolia) 
New Brunswick: The Fundy Coastal Drive is one of the world's top coastal routes, famed for passing by the tides of the Bay of Fundy and this maritime province's most beautiful natural sites. During the first weeks of October, the drive is alight with autumn colours as leaves change. (Fotolia) 
Muskoka, Ontario: Ontario's prime cottage region is just as lovely in fall when the leaves change colour. Late September to early October is the perfect time to escape to this area. (Fotolia) 
Laurentian Mountains, Quebec: From sugar maples to birch trees, Quebec is littered with flora that changes brilliantly in the autumn months. The Laurentian Mountains and the resort town of Mont Tremblant are the best spots to hike, bike or just relax in the colourful setting. Prime viewing times are from late September to late October. (Fotolia) 
Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia: One of the world's best drives, the Cabot Trail, is even more spectacular in autumn as the colours of the trees transform from green to vibrant shades of red, orange and yellow. Colours reach their peak in early October. (Fotolia) 
Bruce Peninsula, Ontario: From the end of September to mid-October, this Georgian Bay area spot is a fantastic combination of fiery colour, calm waterways and crisp weather. The 800 km long Bruce Trail is a great way to explore the colours on foot. (Fotolia) 
Algonquin Provincial Park, Ontario: From the last week of September though October, the leaves in this park are alive with colour. Algonquin is heavily populated with maples and pines, which create a contrasting environment ripe for exploring. Paddle the water trails in a canoe for the most unconventional and natural views of the foliage. (Fotolia) 
Rocky Mountains, Alberta: From late September through October, this area of Alberta, which includes Canadian Rocky Mountains National Parks such as Banff and Jasper, is alive with yellow and gold leaves as aspens and spruces change colour. (Fotolia) 
Vancouver Island: Butchart Gardens in Victoria is the perfect place to see the changing of the leaves on Canada's west coast. The Gardens' Japanese Gardens area (pictured) is especially attractive and alive with the red, gold and orange leaves of maples and colours of chrysanthemums. Viewing times are at their peak in October and November. (Fotolia) Article
